titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Forenoon slipped away in reading two or three Chapters in Hume’s History. Of the latter part of the reign of James I. and beginning of his Son’s.— Walk to Ryswick.— Evening at Count Löwenhielm’s party. Reuterswerd laid up in consequence of a fall down stairs this morning. Whist therefore in his apartment.— Sore throat very troublesome. Came home and went to bed almost sick.

2. Found myself nearly recovered this morning.— Forenoon passed as usual. Dined at Count Löwenhielm’s with a numerous and formal Company. Conversation with General Rewbell, upon Telescopes, Astronomy; the Moon &c.— Evening at Mr: Noel’s party. Reversi with Madame d’Anduaga, Mlle: Bogaert & a french Officer.— Day of course more dissipated than common.

3. The account of the monthly day might dispense me from repeating continually the same thing. Pass’d the Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Large Party.— Quadrill with Mlle: Dumoulin, young Pallavicini, & Bielfeld.— Was careless with its natural consequences.

4. The day upon which the new Administration of the United States commences; and I am still uncertain what the Elections have decided. Every thing hitherto has contributed to accumulate anxiety upon this Event in my mind. Futurity laughs at our foresight. I can only pray for the Happiness and Prosperity of my Country.— Wrote a Letter to my father.— Evening at Count Löwenhielm’s, who returned in the course of it from Amsterdam.— Reuterswerd better, but has not yet left his chamber.— The Evening not remarkably pleasant.— Play’d whist.

5. Find my sore throat still troublesome. Evening an hour or two at Madam Veerman’s, who is yet unwell. Besides my Tacitus and my Blair, I take the opportunity of transient Moments to read occasional publications of the times.— Political testament of Robertspierre.— A forgery of some emigrant who knew not even how to spell the name of the man, whose character he assumes. Yet it contains some curious anecdotes.— Servan.— Etat réel de la France, a la fin de l’année 1795.

6. Mr: George sent us word that he was unwell, and that the party is not to meet this Evening at his house. Pass’d it therefore at Madame May’s.— Whist with her, Mlle: Moliere and General Rewbell. still troubled with a sore throat.

7. Walking this forenoon met Bielfeld. In consequence of his information went in the Evening to the french Comedy. House very full. La mere coupable, a sequel to the Mariage de Figaro, said to be by the same author, Beaumarchais, but a play of a very different character. Its immorality still more pernicious. Its tendency seems to be, to soften the crime of adultery into mere accident or misfortune. Figaro is metamorphosed into a very virtuous man; though still addicted to knavish practices.— The character of an honourable hypocrite disguising the deepest perfidy under a shew of generosity is well conceived but not well executed.— Les amours d’Eté, a collection of Vaudeville’s.

8. Bielfeld called on me this morning. Walk with him. In point of morals and politics he is like most of the partizans of the new school, rigourous to an extreme in theory, and very relaxed in practice. In his conduct he appears to have knowledge enough of the world, and of men, but never makes any allowance for them in reasoning.— Evening at Count Löwenhielm’s.— Whist.— My brother at a ball at Madam Schimmelpenninck’s.

9. Letter from Pitcairn. forenoon employed in answering it.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s party. Conversation with some of the french Officer’s, upon the subject of the War in the Vendee. One of them, who had served there said it was fortunate that affair was finished. They have not been subdued, said he, but destroyed. There is nobody left there. It has cost us at least 400,000 men.

10. Finished my letter to Pitcairn.— Rest of the morning employed as my leisure invariably is, in literary idleness.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s, in a much worse kind of idleness; playing whist.— I will see if I cannot extricate myself at least from this last misspence of time.
11. Weather fair, but extremely cold and windy.— Unwell with an headach. Evening however at Madam May’s.— Play’d à la Macedoine.— I endeavoured to write, in the forenoon, but to no purpose.

12. Sore throat returning. Bielfeld called on me in the forenoon. Walk with him to Scheveling. Weather cold and windy. Excused myself from going to Madam Cneiff’s in the Evening. spent it therefore in reading and of course tolerably to my own satisfaction.
13. Mr: Tucker here, and dined with us. Proposes to return shortly to America. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Play’d at Reversi— A few minutes this afternoon at the sale of books.
14. Again at the sale, which made me late for dinner. Evening at leisure, and pass’d an hour of it at Madam Veerman’s.

15. Captain Mackay arrived yesterday from Paris and proceeded this morning for Amsterdam. His accounts far from pleasing.— At the sale— Writing.— Evening at Count Lowenhielm’s. Play’d Whist. I cannot give an account of the Sensations which continually recur to my mind. My Philosophy is too weak; my apathy, a necessary appearance to the world— Ah! how wide from what is passing within me.

16. I have read through Blair’s Lectures upon Rhetoric and Belles Lettres, which are very good to answer their purpose as a school book. There are a work of taste and information, but not of genius. The style is plain, easy, and often incorrect. The opinions in general are judicious. It is however remarkable that he has placed Milton so low in rank among the Epic Poets: placing him very decisively after Tasso, and perhaps even after Lucan, Voltaire and Camoens.— This is not his place in my estimation.— I am taking up Kames’s Elements of Criticism.— Evening at Mr: Noël’s party— Conversation with Mr: Goldberg.

17. Having this Evening at my own disposal; passed a couple of hours at Mr: Veerman’s. He was gone to the Comedy. Have attended steadily at the sale which finishes this day.— Walk to Loosduynen. Endeavouring to turn the application of my mind upon objects at my choice— This is a sore labour.— I cannot do it for any great length of time nor with any considerable degree of Energy.— These efforts tend but to make me dissatisfied with myself, and discontented with the distribution of intelligence among men.

18. Evening at Madam May’s, and again playing whist with her, Madam de Cneiff and Reuterswerd. The company sufficiently numerous. Gibbons, says in his memoirs that he by no means despises the amusement of a game at cards in the Evening, and Gibbon surely was not an idle man. But I must consider time thus employed as at least lost.

19. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s, at whist; but to shorten it, did not go till near 8 o’clock.— Six is their common hour, for breach of which I was tasked and excused myself. Count Löwenhielm’s talk’d much of his pictures, his Rubens, his Raphael, his Wouwermans, his Teniers, his Jan Steen, &c &c &c.— I am to go one of these mornings and admire them.
20. Evening at Mr: Paravicini’s. Reversi with Madam d’Anduaga, Mr: Bosset, and a french Gentleman. Company large.

21. At the Assembly this forenoon and heard some debates upon the Question whether the Clergy shall be salaried by the State. Upon all these questions which they consider as important many members read written speeches. Their formality often contrasts with the tenuity of the matter they contain.— Poor school of Eloquence. Evening at home. Reading. find it difficult to employ thus two Evenings in the week.
22. Have a bad cold.— Bielfeld called on me.— Walk with him.— Evening at the Count de Loewenhielm’s. He is enlarging his weekly party.— Considerably numerous this day.— Whist.

23. Evening at Mr: Noël’s party.— Company smaller than usual.— Play’d Whist with M: d’Anduaga, Levsen and Bielfeld.— As my time is now employed, I scarcely find a moment for reflection; still less for writing here. The routine in which I find myself engaged is neither very amusing nor very instructive. American Gentlemen. My brother went to Rotterdam.

24. Visit this forenoon from Captain Mackay. My brother returned. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s— He attempted to sell at Auction his house at Visch-Lust, but without success. It would not fetch so much as 4200 florins.

25. Refused an invitation to a party, for the sake of having an Evening to myself. Accordingly pass’d it at home.— Reading in Necker’s last book upon the french Revolution. Received Letters from England and from America; none of the latter more recent than the beginning of December. Remainder of Eveg: perusing the Philadelphia Papers.— Electioneering.

26. Bielfeld called on me this morning; walk with him to Scheveling. Evening at Madam de Cneiff’s. Play’d Whist.— Time hangs heavy upon the present moment and yet rolls with prodigious rapidity upon looking back. Count L.’s invitation to dine with the french Republic. When I came home this Evening, had a letter from General Eustace calling again upon me to relieve him from arrest. He landed it seems at Scheveling. Was ordered away from France. Ordered away from England; and is now stopped here. The secretary to the Committee of internal correspondence told me however, that he would immediately be released.

27. Another card from Eustace at the Heeren Logement. Went to see him there. He is still under arrest.— Evening at the french Play. Mlle: St: Val l’ainée from Paris.— Performed the part of Merope. I was not so well pleased either with the actress or the play as I expected. Mr: Parker dined with us.

28. Engaged again through the day so as to lose my necessary exercise.— Writing.— Evening at M: et Mme: Collot d’Escury’s. Large party. Quadrille with Mlle: Bicker. Mlle: de Milly and a Gentleman I did not know. Mr: Pillet called on me this forenoon for a Passport. This is by far the most troublesome part of my duty.— And a subject upon which I have found it impossible to obtain any instructions whatever

29. Day past again with some irregularity.— Evening at Count Lowenhielm’s party.— Played whist. Find my time rolling over me with more rapidity than for some time past.— May conclude therefore that my mind is not so constantly oppressed with anxiety.— Yet none of the important objects from which it arose have been removed.— Mr: König.

30. No party this Evening at Mr: Noël’s.— Dined at Count Lowenhielm’s. Conversation at dinner with Souque one of Mr: Noël’s secretaries— Evening at the play, to see Mlle: St: Val perform Medée. Liked her better than in Mérope.
31. Mr: Noël called on me this morning to inform me that he is going to be married, to the eldest Miss Bogaert.— Evening, spent an hour or two, at Mr: Veerman’s.

Day. I have hitherto adhered tolerably to the discipline of morning application. Translate as usual my two pages from Tacitus.— The work is very slow in its progress, and perhaps I ought to consider it as beneath my talents. Three hours of daily labour upon translation merely for my own amusement,—is it not a waste of time.— Three hours of daily labour for the instruction merely to be gained from a single author, at my time of life, is it not a shame.— It is barely better than losing them in my bed— And indeed, that is the only alternative— The remainder of the day I pass as has been marked for several months past, and my Evening’s as usual are sacrificed to indolence and health.
